title: How to show that in a metric space, the limit of a sequence {xn} is unique - Quora

response.answer_text: Suppose [math]\{x_n\}[/math] is a sequence in a metric space [math]\big(X,d\big)[/math], and suppose it converges in [math]X[/math] to both [math]{\ell}_1[/math] and [math]{\ell}_2[/math], with [math]{\ell}_1 \ne {\ell}_2[/math]. Then there exist positive integers [math]N_1[/math] and [math]N_2[/math] such that [math]\big| x_n - {\ell}_1\big| < \frac{|{\ell}_1-{\ell}_2|}{2}[/math] whenever [math]n>N_1[/math], and [math]\big| x_n - {\ell}_2\big| < \frac{|{\ell}_1-{\ell}_2|}{2}[/math] whenever [math]n>N_2[/math]. Thus whenever [math]n>N=\max\{N_1,N_2\}[/math], we have [math]\big| x_n - {\ell}_1\big| < \frac{|{\ell}_1-{\ell}_2|}{2}[/math] and [math]\big| x_n - {\ell}_2\big| < \frac{|{\ell}_1-{\ell}_2|}{2}[/math]. But this leads to the impossibility [math]\big| {\ell}_1 - {\ell}_2 \big| = \big| \big(x_n-{\ell}_2\big) - \big(x_n-{\ell}_1\big) \big| [/math] [math]\le \big| x_n - {\ell}_1\big| + \big| x_n - {\ell}_2\big|[/math] [math]< \frac{|{\ell}_1-{\ell}_2|}{2} + \frac{|{\ell}_1-{\ell}_2|}{2} [/math] = [math]\big| {\ell}_1 - {\ell}_2 \big|[/math]. It follows that [math]{\ell}_1={\ell}_2[/math]. [math]\blacksquare[/math] Note. This is the same argument to prove the uniqueness of the limit in Calculus.

I can’t particularly add much to the approach given by Prof. Tripathi. However here is an alternative way of looking at it. All metric spaces are Hausdorff topological spaces. In a topological space [math](X,\tau)[/math] we say that a sequence [math]a_n[/math] converges to [math]a[/math] if [math]\forall U \in \tau , a \in U \ \exists N [/math] s.t [math]  n>N \Rightarrow a_n \in U[/math] That is for every open set including [math]a[/math] eventually our sequence will be in that set. A Hausdorff topological space is one where we can separate all distinct points by disjoint open sets. [math]\forall x,y \in X \ \exists U,V \in \tau [/math] s.t [math]x \in U, y \in V, U \cap V = \emptyset[/math] This also implies that a convergent sequence has a unique limit. You can show this with the definition of Hausdorff combined with the definition of a limit of a sequence. You can show that metric spaces are Hausdorff by defining a basis of your topology with the set of open balls. If you have 2 distinct points you can put each of them in an open ball with radius less than half the distance to the other point.
